segments.text: Okay.
We, as former students, could also tie this to the gravity of the situation as far as A&M was concerned, and specifically the cadet corps.
In any case, a couple of days after that it had been straightened out, and they resumed their functioning.
Their resignation had never been accepted, of course.
But they did not give on the policy.
That stuck.
In other words, hazing was diminished?
Hazing was diminished.
And in fact, or just in... Well, I think we got into this rather deeply earlier in our discussions.
And again, I go back.
You've got to allow these cadet commanders to run their outfits.
And you can't have someone there all the time supervising them.
You'll destroy what organization you have if you tried to observe them all the time, instruct them all the time.
I think, in general, that that policy did stick.
I'm sure there were exceptions.
What they're trying to do is reduce
physical hurt hazing.
But of course, another part of it was to get it into focus so that particularly the freshmen weren't distracted too much of the time from what they're there basically to do.
But in my opinion, when you reduce one form, there's going to be something else increase a bit.
And as long as those cadet commanders
are conscientious in guarding the time that their freshmen and sophomores need to do their studies and guard their rights as we used to have it between recall and taps at 11 o'clock.
Most of them are going to say to it that the hazing is not going to be too destructive.
It's awfully hard to order a specific change in policy for an activity in the cadet corps because you don't have the means to go beyond that cadet commander to do anything about it.
So you've got to have confidence in him that he understands it and in good faith is going to do something about it.
And that's why they made such a point of resistance here.
Instead of accepting the policy and ignoring it, they said, we object to this and we want you to reconsider.
Then when they came back and said we'll put our
officers insignia back on and function, they were saying, in effect, okay, we accept the policy and that means that we've got to do something about it.
When you and two others addressed these students, what kind of response did they give you?
They were in an emotional state when this incident occurred, highly emotional.
They listened politely.
I didn't know at the time whether we'd been very effective or not.
One of my cohorts became very emotional about it.
They were very serious about it, long faces.
And I could see question marks on many of those faces.
A very effective cadet leader had really, you might say, crystallized their action in a rather sudden way.
But I think as those days went by and the implications were known, and their own personal situation
We're known, and I'm sure they got a lot back from Daddy very quickly, particularly the ex-Aggy Daddies.
Sure.
As I say, I'm not sure that this meeting was critical in the process, but I think it helped.
And you made known the Army's view of this insubordination.
Well, of course.
We made known the implications to that.
from the standpoint of the Army.
The Army can't tolerate this sort of thing.
They're under contract with them.
And there are repercussions that this behavior could have on their careers.
And no matter what or who attempted to defend those cadets, they were in a defenseless position.
They can't realize that.
And how were relations between the staff and the student cadets after this episode?
I don't think this really affected too much.
Naturally, they looked to the commandant as the key man involved as far as the military staff was concerned.
And to his credit, President Gilchrist made it clearly known this was his policy.
So it didn't affect too much.
the relationship between the staff and the cadets.
And I think they all respected Colonel Malloy very much.
I don't think he lost any respect over it.

I think, you know, we always have one gripe about somebody in a case like that, and I imagine they did more griping about him than any other one in uniform, but that's because he was the cook in the kitchen.
How had Texas A&M changed in the six or seven years that you had been absent?
Well, I think the major change, of course, had been in the cadet corps because it was decimated by the war.
No fault at A&M.
That was the major change.
And, of course, the student body wasn't too hefty.
I forget how many we had in that cadet corps at that time, but it wasn't very big.
It grew rapidly when the war was over, and we had probably the most significant change that I saw was two, one of which was very pleasing and one of which was displeasing.
We had this great input of veterans, many of whom had been drafted and served.
Many of them had been drafted out of A&M.
Served as enlisted men, came back, got in the cadet corps, and were commissioned when they left.
But the remarkable thing about them was that A&M or no other institution, I suppose, had ever seen the industry on the part of a body of students that they showed.
And their grade achievement was unbelievable.
The bell curve just had to be thrown out the window.
because there were so many of them up there, you know, pay students.
And so that was a, of course, that was a very good thing.
That academic average is way up, and you can imagine the effect it had on the youngsters who were in the classrooms with these.
Of course, many of them came with wives, and the GI Bill was,
seeing them through, and that's a great thing.

The other thing that was such a drastic change from the A&M that I had known, the cadet corps I'd known, and of course in my day when you thought of A&M you thought of the cadet corps because they were the student body, was that the president made the decision in order to really get a hold of this
hazing to put all the freshmen out at Bryan Field.
That was my second year there.
I believe it was the second year.
I was assigned as the PMST of Bryan Field.
I was assigned as the
PMS&T of the freshmen.
And Luke Harrison, who was an ex-Aggie and was on the staff at A&M, was assigned as the commandant representative.
Dean Harrington was the, you might say, he was the dean of the freshmen at Bryan Field.
Later succeeded by my great friend,
Dr. Abbott was the successor to Dean Herring when he was made president of the university.
But this was an extremely interesting thing, even though I disapproved it personally.
I lived out there, lived in the little old apartment in the old hospital building at Bryant Field.
And these cadets lived in those old barracks and went to school in the mess halls and offices.
had their classrooms there, we did their military practical exercises, training, drills, freshman commanding freshman.
We appointed acting officers from among the freshmen who'd had ROTC training in high school.
appointed drill days, we call it.
In other words, the military science course required them to be instructed by the military staff in the practical exercises, usually one afternoon a week.
Senior cadet officers from the main campus would come and work with them on that drill day.
I guess the most interesting aspect of it was how hard those freshmen tried to be good.
I mean, to accomplish what they were asked to do.

And they became excellent in close order drill because they actually would go out and drill more extra time than they would have if they'd been on the main campus and the drill times called by their commanders.
And they wanted to be good fish.
And they were just as disappointed to be out there, of course, as the upperclassmen back at the campus were.
Displeased that they weren't there.
Why was the order put out that they had to stay out there?
It was the hazing problem.
Oh.
So they wanted to separate the fish.
They wanted to just separate.
This was Dr. Gilchrist's idea.
Just completely separate the freshmen, and that would interrupt this hazing bit, see?
That was the basic reason for it.
One thing we did, and let's see, I was there I guess two years with those freshmen.
And that first year, really they had time on their hand.
They did a lot of this extra drilling, but somehow one freshman came to me.
or a group of them came to me, led by a freshman from Dallas, who later became the cadet colonel, by the way, asking if they could form a freshman drill team.
And I told them I thought it was a good idea, but I'd want to know if they felt they could train themselves, because it would be very difficult to have a non-commissioned officer
from the main campus come out there every day to work with them.
They said they assured me that they could do it.
And so they wanted us something distinctive for their uniform, and we planned all this and got approval for it and formed that thing.
Well, as you know, that freshman drill team has won national competition.
Nearly every time it's competed in recent years.
I know when I was in Washington, I say recent years, and when I was in Washington, the last three or four years I was in Washington, they came to Washington for the competition and won each time.
So I, of course, bear pride.
Because I was an observer of the creation of this thing.
They created it themselves.
And thank goodness the authorities come and approved it.
And incidentally, I think that was another effort to show their excellence.
And the first time they were seen by the cadet corps as a whole was at the next spring, at the spring football game, you know, the inter-squad game.
At halftime, we had it set up for this
And it was kind of funny and it was kind of emotional, too.

When they took to the field, they were announced over the loudspeaker system, and when they took to the field, there were boos and the waving of the white handkerchief, and that's an insult to an Aggie, you know.
That's the sign we give the tea sippers.
But they were so good.
You see, they'd been training several months, and the only people who'd ever seen them had been those cadet officers that came out there to work with certain units.
But anyway, they were so good when they finished that that whole student body just took to their feet.
It was really something.
So they were solid then.
They were in.
And it did a lot to...
You know, if the main student body's proud of them, it kind of makes them apart.
Sure, absolutely.
So that was sort of a joining of the fish to the main corps.
Now, when the veterans came back from the Second World War, they did not have to join the corps.
I'm sure some of them
Some of them didn't want to join the Corps after being a veteran of the Second World War.
What was the relationship between the young student in the Corps and the veteran?
Well, it's true that the veterans, they didn't have to wear the uniform.
They didn't have to live in the Corps.
Most of them were very respectful of the Corps.
And, of course, the Corps was very respectful of them.
I think there were some on the part of all of us who were accustomed to looking at that student body.
There were some that didn't like the idea of all those civilian clothes on the campus.
But I don't think there was any resentment of those veterans at all.
I wanted to really respect for them.
And I think it was understood they should have that privilege of not being in the
It was interesting, though, how many chose to be and how many chose to complete their military training there for a commission.
A high percentage, do you think?
I really don't know what the percentage was, but I could just tell from my own classes, my first and last year there.
I was at Bryanfield this year.
I was on the campus two years.
I was just Bryanfield one year.
We'd have a good number.

good percentage in the in our classes but what percentage of the veterans it was I don't know now you had been a student of course at A&M and now you came back as an instructor what what'd you think of that new role that was very interesting revealing and somewhat disillusioning can you explain yeah I say that I say that uh respectfully
But the reason, perhaps I'd better say the disillusioning first.

The disillusionment was that as I went through there as a student and a cadet and an appointed cadet leader, I came to know many of the, of course, well, many of the senior officials of the college, the presidents and the deans and committees and so forth.

and I held them in awe and great respect and I still do and to me they were just sort of a a model of fine men leading a fine purpose in a fine way and all of them perfect gentlemen all of them perfect in their understanding of
cadets and everything else that goes on there.

But when I came back on the staff and got to competing for funds for this activity for the cadet corps, for classrooms that would meet this requirement and so on and so on, I found that they'll fight just as hard for their territory as those deans will, as they will defend
the school as a whole.
I came to see a bit of politics at work, and I guess that's natural.
I never, of course, recognized that politics were working in the university when I was a student.
Politics is not bad, but it's a little disappointing when you feel that maybe old Dean so-and-so is not looking beyond his desk when he's trying to get this done and so forth and so on.
So, that extended a little bit.
as a whole.
What way was it satisfying?
Well, the most satisfying thing was to be working with the Cadet Corps, not just training them in what we were there to train them in, but to get them back on the road and rebuilt.
It was a matter of rebuilding with new material because the material had been taken away.
That was very satisfying.
Sounds like it was successful also.
I think it was.
I've of course been
It's been very painful to me to see the cadet corps steadily recede to a minuscule part of the student body that from just at a distance you can hardly observe them.
I'm sure they're more significant on the campus than that, but I hope that we can see a regrowth in the cadet corps simply because it's good.
It's good for the boys.
the men that get in it.
It's good for the country to have the product of it, and the state.
But we did, I think, do a pretty good job.
We had a very fine, two fine commandants while I was there, and very fine staff.
Very well prepared officers that were carefully selected to come in there those early years after World War II.
It worked.
Now what were your feelings when you were reassigned and when you were reassigned to go to, you said you went to work college.
No, you went to Venezuela right from there.
Went to Venezuela, uh huh.
It was after that, yeah.
What were your feelings about leaving A&M?
Well, I was ready to go because you know three years is a pretty good normal tour and as a matter of fact anytime you leave a job you
You look back and say, well, is there something that I haven't accomplished that should be accomplished?
I'm sure at A&M there's always more to accomplish, but the basic thing we undertook had been put well on the road.
So I didn't feel that I need another year to see my part of this finished.
And I look forward to going to Venezuela, because when that job, I was first called on the phone to ask me if I'd like to have this particular job.
to go to Venezuela with the mission of joining the U.S. Army mission there and for my job create an artillery school in Venezuela.
And it was a fascinating idea to me.
And of course the reason they called me because my record showed I'd had Spanish in school.
asked to be sent to the Army Language School because my Spanish had never been good, and my vocabulary had disappeared.
And they said, no, it's urgent.
If you insist on going to language school, forget it.
So I forgot it.
Went on as was, and it turned out to be a very interesting experience.
I'm moving toward Venezuela now, and I was wondering, you were the
You were the assistant field artillery advisor.
Who was your chief, your boss?
Colonel John Casey was the senior artilleryman there.
He was also deputy chief of mission.
Colonel Marsh was the chief of mission.
In other words, the commander.
So Colonel Casey really functioned primarily as chief of mission.
I mean, deputy chief of mission.
And he really never was active in the
working with the artillery units of Venezuela.
That was basically mine, working with the units and getting this artillery school started.
Okay, let's talk about that.
We were talking a little bit about that last night.
Yeah, well, it was a very interesting challenge, of course, because I think as a matter of background and focus, we ought to point out that this was 1949, late 49, that I arrived there.
World War II is just really still in view in the past.
Many of the Latin American countries had wanted to contribute to the war in some way, but none of them really provided effective fighting forces.
Brazil, as I recall, is the only country in Latin America that fielded an expeditionary force, and they did very little.
They arrived late in the European theater and didn't do much.
I think they went to Italy, as I recall.

I believe that, no one told me this, but I believe that having been through that experience of World War II and seeing how ineffective they were, that the Latin American governments were very conscious of the need that they probably should do something to modernize their military forces in case of need.
And that they were very receptive to a suggestion, by the way, from the United States that we put a military training mission in, I think, in nearly every country down there.
We proposed that and it was accepted.
And I think though the main, one of the reasons that we proposed it was, if I understand it correctly, that we didn't want the history of post World War I repeated.
After World War I, vast numbers of discharged German officers went to South America, and they became an influence in those armed forces down there.
And for you to see that, all you have to do is look at their uniforms today.
And if you can see a movie of a parade in most any Latin American country, even today, that influence is still visible, and most emphatically,
by the way they do the goose step when they pass the reviewing stand.
That came from Germany.
So anyway, there were also Italian officers and so forth in there.
And there was sort of a mix.
Most of them there is private, retired, or discharged individual.
But nevertheless, the influence was there.
And so we replaced that influence and set out to advise and assist in modernizing
armed forces of those Latin American countries.

At the same time, when we back off and look at it, and even when I was there I could see it, at the same time our government and the State Department was making judgments on really how modern or how much should these countries have, how much modernity and how much equipment and what kinds.
They resented that.
It was hard to see, I guess, that there was any external threat to Latin America.
They were not prone to ally among themselves.
In fact, more prone to fight among themselves, although there's been no serious fight for decades among them.
But I could see, as an observer in Venezuela, that the Venezuelans' officers felt that someday they were probably going to have to fight Colombia.
or someday they're probably going to have to fight Guayana.
I guess when they look around their borders, Brazil was, there's so much jungle between them and the nearest road to Brazil that that wasn't a worry, but their other neighbors were.
So anyway, our efforts- What about the threat of communism?
I beg your pardon?
What about the threat of communism?
At the time I was there, it was not significant at all.
Not as significant at all.
This occurred subsequently, that threat.

But I think in the form of general comments, again, it was a little bit frustrating to be there to convince the Venezuelans that we could help them modernize and make them effective armed forces and then have their request for
Venezuela could buy.
They had the money.
That oil and iron and everything.
To be refused by the State Department an order of cannon or fighter aircraft or whatever, Navy ships, it just didn't seem to make much sense to the Venezuelans.
They resented that.
They resented it.
It seemed clear to me that
the leadership in Venezuela was also conscious of the fact that, aside from this stepbrother position they were in vis-a-vis the United States, that we didn't seem very important to them.
They didn't seem very important to us.
They got that impression.

important matters of national security or international security and international affairs and economic affairs were elsewhere we took for granted the economic relationships and we also took for granted the dominance of the political relationship our dominant position that's the way they viewed it but where we had money to go in to help people it was primarily in europe and where we had strategic
considerations to really come to grips with outside of Latin America.
It was in Europe and in the East.
So those people aren't unlearned down there, and they're pretty intelligent people, and I think they found it very difficult to remain good allies.
as opposed now, and not opposed, but it's easier for them to be good trade partners because it's just natural that we trade together.
So anyway, that was the atmosphere in which I worked.
But my job was a very fixed and simple one.
And the complexities were small, but many.
The job was to get an artillery school established and they never had one.
I was surprised to learn after I got down there that they didn't have a basis to spring from, a base to spring from.
They didn't really have a trained artillery branch.
They had nothing that resembled a school.
They had nothing that resembled a universal
artillery training program for advancing officers in their capabilities.
And therefore, this school concept started with me.
Well, that makes you feel pretty self-conscious, you know, and feel the responsibility of it.
So, I'd been there, got there in September of 49, and in November, the G3 of the Armed
forces called me in.
He's the one that, of course, had planned this, and asked me if I would start a little informal class there at the Ministry of Defense with some artillery officers just to get started.
The Venezuelan G3?
Venezuelan G3.
And the idea, I guess, as much as anything else, would get me prepared, which made sense.
But I told him, well, you know, my Spanish isn't very good.
He's very good in English.
I've got some Spanish to learn.
And also, since I've gotten here and seen what has to be done, I have written to Port Sale, Oklahoma for lesson material so that we can start a course.
We can design one for our needs here and get it going.
But I said, the main problem right now is the language.
But if you'll give me a translator and allow that
you know, extra time it takes, sure, I'll get something going.
He said, oh, no, our policy is there'll be no translators in any of the classes.
I said, well, then it seems to me that you're going to have to give me a little more time to get prepared.
He said, oh, I think you can do it.
You know, I said, you can do it.
And we need to get going.
So I didn't argue the matter.
I took it to my chief, the missions.
At that time, it wasn't Colonel Marsh.
At that time, it was Colonel Marsh's predecessor, who was very fluent in Spanish, beautifully, spoke it beautifully.
And I presented the problem, and I fully expected that he'd support me, and we'd get this thing into reason.
He said, well, I think you can do it.
So there I was.
Anyway, all I tell this for you is that it really forced me to get that Spanish or go home.
It's that simple.
Well, as you know, Spanish is probably the easiest language in the world to learn and use.
But anybody's got to have a vocabulary.
Sure.
It's easy to drive nails, but you've got to have nails.
So what did you do?
So what we did was start this little course, and I went over every other day for two hours.
This gave me a lot of time to struggle with it.
I would do my lesson plans, have the mission translator translated into Spanish.
I would study it.
I would rewrite it in the Spanish that I felt I could use.
And I'd try my best to memorize it.
And I'd make a little series of rites or exercises to be done with paper
I had to have some other means than my Spanish.
Well, this went on from late November until March of the next year.
By March, I didn't have to use the translator.
I didn't have to memorize the Spanish.
I had learned, relearned my basic grammar and
Of course, I never lost the pronunciation.
And I had acquired a pretty decent military vocabulary, which was new to me in any case.
Then in March, we started, that was just sort of a makeshift course.
The same officers then joined.
How many were there?
There were about eight officers, a small group.
It turned out it was a very wise thing to do.
I wouldn't have gotten prepared any other way under those policies.
So in March we started the first full-time, not full-time, the first everyday series course.
For two hours every day?
This was two hours every day.
Plus, on certain days we'd have exercises that would take a whole half a day.
They had a little place called El Valle, the valley, in which there was a small military installation.
And it was a little military reservation.
And we could shoot the 105 howitzers in there.
We had very short minimum ranges.
We could hardly shoot over 2,000 yards in a very narrow corridor, and therefore, a very small selection of targets to practice them on.
But we could get the mechanics in, and we could get the guns.
So you could give them some on-the-job training.
So we could give them some practical training.
few officers in this class, including most of those who were in that first class.
And about halfway through this course, which ran until that fall, two young officers, lieutenants, returned from the United States Artillery School.
And they assisted me, not full time.
They had other jobs, but they'd assist me.

classes but I was the instructor then when that training was finished we went to the field that year first time I guess they've done a field exercise in true sense in their careers and well that's a long story of how we found it but we found a beautiful piece of terrain out in the hinterland about 150 kilometers from Caracas it would have been a credit to any
service school.
It was just terrain that individuals in the government owned some of it, but just wasn't occupied.
Minimal roads into it, as you might imagine.
And we spent, all told, three weeks out there applying what these young, what these people had been trained to do in artillery.
And our old saying in the artillery is, what you've got to learn is how to shoot, move, and communicate.
But in order to do those things effectively, you've got to be out in the field to do it.
On maneuvers.
That's right.
Well, it was highly successful from their point of view for several reasons.
One, it went very well.
They found that they could do the things that they'd been trained to do.
in the classroom and in that little practical exercise area to do.
They were the only school class in the Venezuelan Army that got to go to their field exercise.
They'd been planned for the other branches too, but the dictator President Delgado Chabot had been assassinated just in a few months, a few weeks, I guess, before we were supposed to go.
And again, this G3 felt that we should go because we were ahead of the others.
But all the others were canceled because of that incident.
And so that kind of made these artillerymen feel they were ahead, too.
Furthermore, the succeeding dictator, Paris Jimenez, came out for the final exercise, and he was so impressed.
Because it's not that it was...
So absolutely excellent, but it was so far beyond what they'd ever known before.
He was so impressed, and we did a full blue shoot and communicate exercise for him with a very impressive artillery fire for him to observe.
He ordered that next year there would be a combined field exercise mission.

infantry supported by artillery and engineers and signal and with armor they had an armored battalion or two and so actually the next year we did that but as far as the course and the artillery school was concerned after that first year of training and winding up with that initial field exercise then the artillery school of Venezuela was formally chartered
And we took Major Jose Quevedo to be the commandant.
He was promoted to lieutenant colonel.
He was one of the three majors in that first course.
I was his advisor.
The two young officers who'd been trained at Fort Sill were put on the teaching staff, along with
Were those Venezuelans?
They were Venezuelans.
Along with the Venezuelan officers from that first course who were outstanding.
And then we had the first full-time course.
Run by the Venezuelans.
Run by the Venezuelans.
And this full-time course, as was the one that I taught you,
And as all the courses in the Venezuelan Army became officers' courses like that in the other branches, those were qualifying courses for promotion.
Anyone who didn't go through that course or pass that course didn't get promoted.
So you could see the motivation that attended.
That was a very great aid to me, of course, in the very beginning.
It also was a problem because there
You would expect standards to be somewhat different in various ways against two civilizations, comparing two civilizations, theirs and ours.
But initially, I set the basic standards for that initial course.
And then when we formed this school, we had to set some of the norms.
And one of them had to do with ensuring that each officer did his own work.
because he would scramble to be sure he passed and got qualified for promotion and everything.
Well, those standards that we established in that first course that I taught were basically applied to the new thing, and they really had a new set of standards, too, for conductive classes.
And what were those standards?
And that spread.
It required, of course, that an officer be absolutely above reproach on doing his own work, whether it was work to be accomplished outside of the classroom by him, or in the classroom, or on a test.
They just never observed such a standard seriously before.
And I guess the big difference was this qualifier for promotion.
In other words, you've seen professors
that say, I don't care how you get it, just so you get that information in your head.
But when you're grading this fellow against that one for purposes of promotion, it's got to be different than that.
It's got to be very strict.
They had not had that strict standard.
Another standard we had was that a very important means of instruction is the demonstration.
In their military academy or

And the standard was that a poor demonstration is worse than no demonstration, and so you'll rehearse the demonstration out on the side of the students as many times as necessary to make it as near perfect as you can expect it to be.
That's something they'd never really heard of.
Another standard was that no class would be conducted without appropriate
aids to instruction, basically graphical aids.
The various means of instruction, the least effective is the lecture because of the inability of our mind to record words.
If you see something done, you're going to remember more than if you just heard about it.
And of course, if you do it, you're going to remember much more
than the other two combined.
So anyway, those were the kind of standards we tried to get in there, and it worked.

And it spread to the other schools, because at this point, because of that misfortune of everybody being grounded in their fortresses, so to speak, when the president was assassinated, except the artillery corps, we got a head up in the scene.
How'd you get along with the Venezuelan soldiers?
How'd the American army and the Venezuelans get along?
We got along fine.
And I think our training mission, I forget how many officers we had.
We had, it seems to me, about 20 officers, 20-odd officers in that mission, and a corresponding number of non-commissioned officers.
And we were spread out advising the various branches and the various headquarters.
We got along well.
I will say this, though, speaking of differences.
In the Venezuelan Army, the personality of the person makes a lot more difference than it does in our Army.
I mean, you know, we're accustomed in our Army to accepting a leader or a cohort based on the way he operates and what he gets accomplished.
But the personality is more important there.
